text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name MRS. DORTHEA (IRENE) (HORTON) CALVERLE

Present Address BOX 490, DAWSON CREEK, B.C.

Pioneer Address WALDECK, SASK. LATER SWIFT CURRENT

Year you came to Saskatchewan 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

This is largely from memory, but my grandmother often lived until she was 86, and in her later years with us here.

This questionnaire is intended for people who came early, before 1920, and those who came after that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

5. What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

7. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

8. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

9. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

10. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

11. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

12. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
1. In the first ten years how many houses were there in your town? How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (Give approximate figures.)

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

4. Have you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done at home?

5. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

6. Did you ever have "tea" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilting, or other such activity?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, what drives or dances in town? Describe.

8. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

9. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times—every two weeks, every week, every month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

- cannot remember very much

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

all the school was the centre except for Sunday when Waldesh, 32 miles away, was visited

9. When was your first community hall built? - Mr Walter Fox could answer. (Waldesh, Sask)

What material was it made of? - How large was it? (not sure)

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? -

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

yes

How were babies and small children provided for?

They lay on the floors in the school house

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Most provided barn space and fodder - if they were brought outside!

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Authors, Flit and the men played cards over wives protests.

Was there card playing for a prize? no

What dances were popular?

our community didn't dance in early years.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

mostly the church people frowned upon it, but I remember my grandfather playing cards downstairs the night of the earthquake. Grandmother thought they had started a fight!
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box suppers, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, planning, etc.)

If you have not described these on the school questionnaire, give data.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it—the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the city, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you forced to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home or for community gatherings? Explain.

People known to have played it, but not remembered my knowledge, they might have been early down south. I'm sure it was a game!
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

None in our homestead community.

There was plenty in Swift Current!

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Every couple that married were "celebrated." By the couple didn't come out and where the crowd in - they were pulled out.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Checkers, croquet, quilting bees were common, but as nearly all settlers were young, my grandmother the local midwife, I seem always to be out on calls or entertaining confinement, everybody had a "stereopticon" viewer!

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The school district

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Mr. Ted Lee or Mr. Walter Fox of Swift Current could answer.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
3.

12. What attendance at formalities, or "gawking," do you remember in small towns, such as glove shops, etc., when calling, visiting, or attending ceremonies in parlor, etc.? 

There was plenty of socializing in our rural community.

13. Was the church known in your community? 
Describe what you remember about churches, talking how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular in visiting or social activities whatever you can when some changes occurred during the war years.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in your community belonged to it?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, all) etc.)?

- sheepskin, pom-pom pullaway
- catch - skating
- slough
- left-handed sleighriding

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

- London Bridge - drop handkerchief
- three-deep
- sleighriding
- many imaginative games
- dolls
- paper dolls (from the old magazines)
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the names of each, place where it was located, class or classes within its limits, and whether it was only an organization within a relatively small area (for example, a school district), or had centers in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the form for questions for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

Lesson Review for storytime

What materials are used by organizations?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc., telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), likewise how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lanterns and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mushlatypes, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

Lemon Drops - drop lemon seeds into water, many will float. Use a magnifying glass to see the seeds.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *skating - snowballing*

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *yes as above*

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *all joined in our family*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *In winter grandmother sewed and embroidered but children and men played after chores were done.*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *yes - but I don't remember much about it. I seem to have read a great deal.*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *about 1908 at the creek North of Waldick*

26. Who organized it?  
   *we picked goosberries*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
   *I think so. We were first settlers in Waldick district*

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *ball games, and usual children's games - and gooseberries!*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *a general lunch*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *bread and butter, potato salad, ham, deviled eggs, pickles, cakes, cookies, cream puffs, coffee and lemonade at least*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *We left early in morning - I remember the cows singing in the wagon coming home behind our oxen.*
22. What other games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Face," "Lions," "Whistlers," or others? (Note: These are not listed.)

Tell the whole family in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

In winter, the activities were much more interesting than during the summer months.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, rocks, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

Yes, but I don't remember much about it. We seem to have had a great deal.

PIONEERS AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

About 1900 at the school yard.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

For the entire community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If so, what activities were included?

It's not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

Family games and general activities.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

A general lunch.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Bread and butter, potato salad, ham, dill pickles, cake, cookies, corn muffins, and brownies.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

We left early in the morning and returned home by dark.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Just the gooseberry storms!

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

My grandfather always played with us, but he died in 1927—croquet, skipping rope, etc., etc.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as the large community picnic school or Sunday School picnic, family picnics, etc., tell how they differed and why they were held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, society young people), etc.

37. For what games was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such
   as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known
   hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
   names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many
   books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

   "Our radio" - Shakespeare. "Tennyson's Poems." Byron's poems. Complete Dictionary.
   Webster's. Several Bibles - "In the Masters Steps."
   Some big book I recipes for making and
   doing almost everything. A medical book
   "The Opening of the childhood." Burn by Poe and a
   number of poems I cannot remember also all
   those we had at home. Books with them:
   "True and False Memory." "Vacant of Wakefield"
   "Scott's Words of the Bible." "High School"
   geographies, History etc. I had read them
   all before I was 10.

43. How many of your neighbors exchanged books with them?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

   We lent ours.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

   Yes - grandfather bought me about 20 books
   on a similar site for Christmas 1907. No fairy tales!
   All good old stories - and Little Women.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

   None that I recall except "Hartbutts"
   Story of the Bible" and later "This Own Anne"

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?
   Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? - about 1900-02

   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to
   read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading
   material?

   They read every word I mean! and thought my readers too trivial
   for words. I read aloud at home daily
   from my solid books and learned
   dreams of poetry.
7.

40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community pictures?
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).
Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came away? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible, and titles, and how many you brought, and that you read.) (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

43. How many of you read newspapers? Books? Magazines?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you ever lend your books after you came away? Give details.

46. What books did you read?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

48. Was there a school library? If so, when did it begin? About 1918-19.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?

They read every word and knew it and they read aloud at home by themselves my poetry.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it
   contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian,
   and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

   The early Swift Current library was
   in the cloakroom of the Grade VIII
   room, on shelves.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to
   the west? "Farmers Advocate," "Family Herald"
   and some Winnipeg farm journal.
   maybe "Country Bible" and all
   the govt bulletins they could lay
   hands on, and the Sunday school
   papers, which were devoured entire.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped cer-
   tain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading
   material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   Several books. I mentioned above, in
   fact nearly all of them.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your
   early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   Grandfather died. Grandmother was
   always hard-working, but I never lacked
   reading.
8.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   If so, when did it start?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? (Name all)

and some Winnipeg newspapers, and all the government papers they could pay hands on and the Sunday school papers which were delivered during.

Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

52.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages or reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

36. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
   An organ, guitar, banjo, and harmonica.

37. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
   Autoharp, fiddles, and accordion.

38. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

39. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   There was always a hymn sing and old songs around the campfire when friends were in town visiting in the community (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

40. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? All the hymns "In the Glorious Morning," "Falling Leaf," "Singing Through," "Red Wagon," "Golden Hill," "On the Road," "God's Old Summertime," and all the Stephen Foster songs.

41. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.
   My people being Americans, they sang patriotic songs that the Ontario people were very fond of.

42. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   Grandfather used to - but I cannot remember any.

43. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?
   Who started it? How long did it continue?

   Mr. George Swift started it.

   What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? Mr. Arthur Ward of the Fox District became well known as a bird hunter and observer.

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? If so, give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. In what area do you feel most important in your community now as compared with the early days? Was it the person for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any collections, such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you notice any changes in the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? English.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

Mr. Arthur Ward of the Fox District became well known as a bird hunter and observer.

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading habits of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)
Oxford.

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
